Software

Software

Digital fascial infrastructure - a connective tissue that both connects and separates different parts of our digital systems.

I have been fascinated with fascia lately - people with close ties to bodywork have started to focus in on our connective tissue as a means of healing and (re)balancing bodies. Unlike the more commonly studied muscles and organs, it has been largely overlooked until recently - partially because it's seen as a passive tissue. Fascia is incredibly visible, spreading across a body - but also invisible, connecting the parts of our bodies more synonymous with what people might consider the 'stuff of bodies.' It blurs the lines and distinctions between body parts and reminds us that our internal systems are literally interconnected and held together by something we've largely overlooked.

— contributed by Jessica Rajko

software

software

some combination of:
- a mental model of how a computer is configured to accomplish some task (where do the patch cables on the eniac go? are any tubes burnt out? what am i being told to do? what am i trying to do?)
- the symbolic representation of that configuration (source code, patch diagrams, prose descriptions)
- the actual execution of that task on a computer (how we might observe the system state, the inputs, the outputs)

some arguments try to synthesize these understandings, some try to eliminate some of them (Kittler's There Is No Software suggests it's all just voltages in a machine, for example)

— contributed by angus fletcher

Structured Programming

Structured Programming

Software engineering. The industrialization and standardization of higher-level programming languages, hegemonically requiring programmers to deal with abstractions over numerical processes. Structured programming means programmers create software using software, effectively eroding the distinction between programmer and user.

Importantly, structured programming emerges in an effort to control quality, costs, and programmers as well as their techniques, “protecting” programs from programmer alteration/imagination. Structured programming is generally considered successful when it hides—and therefore secures—the machine.

— contributed by Lauren Monzon

structured programming

structured programming

a way of programming that favours a hierarchical decomposition of a program. roughly:

  • think of your program as a broad series of steps
  • write down those steps
  • think about the steps in each of those steps
  • write down those steps
  • repeat until you have a program

if the only way you abstract steps is by subroutine or function calls (as opposed to using GOTOs or jumps), the resulting program is shaped like a tree, which is easier for other programmers to read and understand at multiple levels of detail. this choice to emphasize legibility implies a move towards programming as a collaborative or industrial process

— contributed by angus fletcher

Structured Programming

Tailored Experience

Tailored Experience

......

~ As a designer of tech providing ‘tailored experiences’ what would it do/look like? ~

**Bio-technologies of the five senses that process and communicate visual/auditory/gustatory/olfactory/haptic data across all living organisms. Biotechnologies will expand to encompass additional, synthaesthetic, or nonhuman senses as recognized.
**Tailored Experience Tech synthesizes any wave/particle form as information, expanding our communication and archive of knowledge across species. accordingly, tailored experience technologies are available to any organism.
**Tailored Experience Tech stems from DNA quantum computing hardware, deploying nucleotides as the basis for quantum circuits that depend on interaction/entanglement for computing. This wetware (computing tech composed entirely of organic material) allows for not only bio-integrated software & modifications, but also the capacity to physically manifest tailored-experience tech in any form. Importantly, external structure and internal programming are interdependent and unified.
**Tailored Experience Technologies are powered by localized renewable energy infrastructures (e.g. nanotube spaghetti mo-cap, solar, hyrdopower).
**Production and distribution mechanisms for tailored experience tech are common/social possessions, there exists no programmer-user binary, only collaborator/co-creator.
**GUI is self-governed: ultimately, each organism determines what they want their tech interfaces to look like, compute, & measure.
- Upon login, tailored experience technologies request co-creators build an alter interface reflecting past histories, present grounding practices, and future goals each co-creator wants to orient around. In this way, those engaging with tailored experience technologies learn to generate not only physical but also digital items and interfaces.
- Tailored Experience Altars also foreground self-determined markers of time, understanding time as a symbol of a relationship that a group of beings “biologically endowed with the capacity for memory and synthesis, establishes between two or more continua of changes, one of which is used by it as a frame of reference or standard of measurement for the other or others.”
**DATA COLLECTION IS PRIVATE & SELF-DETERMINED (stored within one’s body or external bio-hard drive & decoheres after a self-determined period of time?).

‘Tailored Experience’ - wet, hot entangled technologies of self-governance

Terms &amp; Conditions

Terms & Conditions

We covered our faces but it wasn’t enough. The matrix was all around us, and its eyes saw everywhere, and i’m not sure how we got here, but i’m pretty sure we always have been, and man, how can we build ourselves, when it already feels like they’ve done it for us? Seeing. We began to wonder if maybe the power was in it. Maybe we could see through the hardware. Find a way out and make ourselves anew.

We know we have to do work internally, as we learn and unlearn what it means to reveal your personal data to you. We recognize our features and information are not exhaustive or any close to complete. We invite you to re-imagine and contribute resources that could normalize the system. Touching, smelling, and hearing, we encourage you to sense what a SOFT ware may empathize with you. We adapt collectively as we press on.

Together, we meet in old janitor closets to collectively imagine a new path forward in this world of the matrix panopticon. Sometimes, we walk through its streets together, simply notice and listen to it. With this, we began to understand that to each person, the matrix presents itself slightly differently according to what variation of its ruling ideology is most palatable to each of us as individuals. the matrix was feeding us all different worlds, telling us to pay attention to different parts of the street, showing us the ads that fed our hopes and fears and reinforced a sense of isolated self. It uses algorithms to construct our desires and thus control our actions. And so, almost with the clarity that falling into sharply cold water brings, we understand Divide and Conquer to be the secret impulse behind the matrix; we know now what we must build to regain our collective liberty.

In an effort to build a new lens, we ignited our innate power through the realities of what’s within us. We started by creating a network rooted in what lies beyond the matrix and additionally our physical shell. A system reliant on what we’re made of — matter. We created a shift from the codes of conduct and standards of beings that previously pushed us into precarious corners of humanity, and co-opted and scrambled the various information technologies made to police and extinguish our bodies. As a result, we developed a complex soft ware to fuel and sustain the machine herself through our own thermal energies—disengaging from the power of the matrix, and re-engaging naturally to rebuild ourselves and mother earth.

In collaboration with Tash Nikol Smith, Cameron Granger, Ilona Altman and Miranda Shou.

— contributed by Miranda Shou

Trust Plane

Trust Plane

Inspired by the orthogonality of Mann's "Veillance Plane", I tried to figure out how we might structure our understanding of trust in a similar way – how does trust change in response to differences of power, what is "negative" trust, etc.

The X axis comprises how trust is practiced between actors with different levels of power, whereas the Y axis expressed how trust is interfaced with among people with roughly equal positions in various power structures.

References:
Steve Mann's "Veillance Plane"

— contributed by connor trotter

Transcoding

Transcoding

When I was in high school, my friend invited me to have dinner with his grandparents. His grandfather showed us his vinyl record collection. He told us how he wished he had his records stored in computer audio files and then asked us if we could figure out how to do that. We said we could try.

When we looked at his turntable, we noticed it had a cable that could be plugged into speakers. We plugged that into his desktop computer. I had heard of this open-source software that could be used to record audio, so I suggested we download and try it. Once we had installed it, we found out how to set an input and hit record. Then we started played the record on his turntable. The program had a promising waveform, but we had to wait for the record to finish before we knew if it worked. We went to eat dinner. Afterwards, we came back, stopped the recording, trimmed it, and exported it to an mp3 file. We had transcoded the playing of the vinyl record into an audio file.

We played the recording for my friend’s grandparents. They were happy with it. You could still hear the scratchy artifacts of listening on a turntable. The grandfather told us about the artist. It was one of his favorites. A Brazilian guitar player. “Nobody else can play like that,” he said.

— contributed by Ryan Patterson

transcoding

transcoding

The first portable electronic I owned was a PlayStation Portable. In addition to the mesmerizing collection of games available at launch, including FIFA Soccer 2005, Need for Speed Underground Rivals, and Wipeout Pure, the PSP paired with a large-enough memory stick “Pro Duo” was a movie-lovers paradise, granted you had a good collection of DVDs and HandBrake. HandBrake could turn a 90-minute film into glorious 480p in less than thirty minutes. I also remember having to transcode any iTunes music that I tried to put on my PSP— I think that was in the early days of DRM-protected iTunes downloads.

— contributed by Trevor Tatham

UX/UI

UX/UI

UX/UI: User Experience Design/User Interface Design.

Use Experience Design:
To design the user journey throughout a specific course of action; this includes anticipating, managing, and guiding user behavior to achieve a specified task or goal. It's a goal-driven and user-orientated approach of design that answers the question of How to.

User Interface Design:
To design the interface (= the utmost visible layer to the user) that could be visual and/or audible taking into consideration user-accessibility. It translates UX into tangible/testable steps to reach the specified goal desired by answering questions of Why that mostly arises from cognitive psychological concepts.

— contributed by Sara K.R.

User amplification

Wetware

Wetware

An artificial computer entirely composed of organic material, such as living neurons. 

Combining software and hardware into one interdependent system, wetware computers are thought to be capable of 'thinking for themselves.' The structure of wetware represents a model where "external shape and internal programming are unified," so that changes in programming/communication between molecules in a wetware device would represent a physical change in form.

Wetware is differentiated from biorobotics in that the latter can be fashioned from nonorganic materials. There has been limited success with wetware construction/prototyping, including the development of a computer capable of simple addition by harnessing leech neurons at the Georgia Institute of Technology in 1991.

— contributed by Lauren Monzon

white racial frame

white racial frame

A framing of race that exists through the forceful framing of other races as inferior while refusing to evaluate itself.

— contributed by Ryan Patterson

White Racial Frame

White Racial Frame

The architecture of White supremacy that posits Whiteness as invisible, neutral, entirely abstracted into the mainframe. The blank white GUI, replete with a blinking cursor; the general culture of light. A transposition of culpability, to be replaced with weaponised fragility. 𝘐𝘵 𝘴𝘰𝘶𝘯𝘥𝘴 𝘭𝘪𝘬𝘦 𝘧𝘪𝘤𝘵𝘪𝘰𝘯, 𝘣𝘶𝘵 𝘪𝘵'𝘴 𝘮𝘰𝘳𝘦 𝘭𝘪𝘬𝘦 𝘴𝘤𝘪𝘦𝘯𝘤𝘦 𝘧𝘢𝘤𝘵.

white racial frame

a set of beliefs and ways of seeing that position whiteness as central, objective, heroic, and inevitable. it allows white judgment of other people to be taken as authoritative, axiomatic, free from criticism

william shockley

william shockley

most commonly, we're taught that william shockley was the nobel prize winning father of the transistor. second most commonly, we're taught that he was a bad enough boss/colleague that he was indirectly responsible for the founding of fairchild's semiconductor arm and perhaps the semiconductor industry.

rarely do we remember that shockley wrote a report suggesting that a mainland invasion of japan would result in more casualties than the use of the atomic bomb. he became an ardent eugenicist and 'race scientist', and stands today as an emblem for technologists' willingness to celebrate technical achievement and readily forget, de-emphasize, or legitimize enthusiastic participation in systems of subjugation and oppression.

— contributed by angus fletcher

Zoom

Zoom

Zoom is a video-conferencing platform that became extremely popular in the United States during the COVID-19 pandemic. Within weeks many professional institutions and universities mandated the use of Zoom by employees rather than other more familiar video-conferencing platforms. Though applications such as Skype and FaceTime have built their names to be synonymous with the act of video-calling, Zoom immediately overcame their familiarity through mere ubiquity. Zoom’s popularity has raised privacy concerns for many critics of networked technology, and though the FBI issued a warning about Zoom’s teleconferences being hijacked to display violent imagery and hate speech, it is still considered a popular platform for mass video-conferencing in the United States as of August 2020.

— contributed by American Artist

Introduction

This is the Dictionary of Dark Matters.186 During the Summer of 2020, Dark Matters was taught by American Artist with the assistance of Zainab Aliyu. For ten weeks, we stewarded and taught this class over the video platform Zoom. 559 Thirty students convened over and through national borders to study 482 alongside us and with one another. We engaged in intimate practices of unlearning, deep listening and reflection. Most importantly, we studied “under the university,” a framing we borrow from theorists Fred Moten and Stefano Harney.

The class, titled Dark Matters: On Blackness, Surveillance,487 and the Whiteness of the Screen, takes it's namesake from Simone Browne's book Dark Matters: On the Surveillance of Blackness. This critical text winds personal, political and pop-cultural narratives of racial gaze442 and sousveillance 476 to address the origins of so many recurring dynamics of power that operate through high technology. The readings in our class began with Wendy Chun's critique of software 473 and ideology's 313 tendencies towards

obfuscation, 386 as well as American Artist's Black Gooey Universe 100 and imagining of an unsovereign technology. Over the four sessions that this class has been taught, we have introduced authors to the curriculum such as Jackie Wang, David N. Pellow, Lisa Sun-Hee Park and Ruha Benjamin. Selected work by these authors hold the origins of the interface 100 to account for the continuation of racial capitalism, 100 the debt state, 100 colonialism, 100 the white racial frame, 100 and other global practices that are deeply rooted in American colonial history.

Dark Matters reminds us about the panoptic 100 models and codes that construct the world we live in, their underlying ideologies, as well as the need for our consistent reckoning. 100 This class has given us intentional time to tend to ourselves as we contend with this predatory state, 100 to study the material while existing within the systems we are learning to name. Together, we studied theory, but theory is nothing without the lived experiences that inform it. The duration of our time together coincided with the COVID-19

pandemic, the ongoing movement for Black Lives (particularly in response to the murder of George Floyd), and the calling out of various academic institutions and places of work (including our own) for their perpetuation of anti-blackness. 100 These issues framed all of our conversations and largely informed our communal ethic 100 of sharing, creating and relating with one another. Through our co-learning, we can better understand how structures are compromised, and we can begin to imagine strategies for future resistance, and what an outside to the structures we participate in might actually look and feel like.The self-published book you are reading is the culmination of all of that thought. It is a 500+ page (and growing) collaborative people's dictionary100 written over the course of ten weeks. It is an abundance100 of poetry, prose, creative writing, personal history and illustration filled with terms we have come across during our time together. For transparency, 100 every voice within the dictionary is uniquely represented with the

contributor's preference in typography. By archiving our histories and inserting our human 100 experiences into the critical theories we are learning, we are looking inwardly and actively engaging with the way we move through the world. It feels increasingly necessary, helping us to ask not only about the technologies, processes and policies that govern civil liberties, but also about whose bodies and freedoms remain captive.

— contributed by American Aritst and Zainab Aliyu

This book and its digital counterpart, darkmatters.xyz, was designed by Zainab Aliyu (cover designed in collaboration with American Artist), edited by Jessica Rajko, and assembled with the support of Are.na and Callil Capuozzo.

abolition

abolition

to talk about abolition is to:

  • name a root cause, system of oppression, practice, framework or idea (slavery, policing, imprisonment)
  • recognize that what we have named was created and is maintained by us
  • to declare what we have named unjust, and state our intent to resist and dismantle it

to do abolition is to:

  • talk, read, write, ask questions, write letters, listen, learn from those who were struggling while i was denying, criticize myself, say we'll show up and then show up, fail, bounce back, fight, ask nothing from what we want to abolish and give nothing to it, support and care for each other, honestly i don't know all the ways but hope to learn

— contributed by angus fletcher

Abstraction

Abstraction

Abstraction can refer to the extraction of certain methods or attributes of a data structure in order to simplify the interface with that data. It is a representation of the data not the data itself.

The GUI is an abstraction of the Program, the Operating System is an abstraction of the Hardware

— contributed by Matt Ross

Abstraction

Abstraction

Abstraction

The linguistic art of translating a set of terms and processes into a different one, such that the new set holds a different set of assumptions and scope. This transformation allows a different range of thought, since it lets a person forget a set of details and focus elsewhere.

— contributed by Paras Sanghavi

Abstraction

Abstraction

Is abstraction always lossy? (that is, do we always lose information by its process)

— contributed by Krystal Maughan

Acequia

Acequia
40

Acequia (“ah-SIH-kee-ah”)
It’s more than just a ditch - it sustains life.

Acequias are gravity-ﬂow trenches that are part of an irrigation system in, among other locations, the South Western USA regions, but whose origins go back around 10,000 years, to arid areas in the Middle East. Muslims brought their acequia, "derived from the Arabic as-saqiya (that which gives water)" technology with them when they settled in Spain and the Spaniards, as colonizers, transported it to the new world. At the end of the 16th Century the technology migrated north to what became the USA’s south western states.

An acequia stream or system of streams, diverts water from a river to grow crops to feed people. The Spanish settlers from Mexico diverted water from the Rio Grande river to build acequia to water their crops and feed the people in the newly settled missions.

The acequias facilitated water seeping through the ground to aquifer or water table below. This cycle sustained life. However contested water rights and greed threatens the sustainability of the system.
Source:

41

https://www.aramcoworld.com/Articles/September-2016/How-The-Middle-Eastern-Irrigation-Ditch-Called-Ace

— contributed by Teresa Snider-Stein
42

Acequia

Acequia

A communal system for water distribution within a community, origins Mexico. With this system, there is no Sewage and Water Board. With European privatization of water, it becomes a “natural resource” to be extracted where fights over who has to pay for sewage can occur.

— contributed by Sus Labowitz

time to build, propose, nourish, envision, speak to power, collaborate, invite, apologize, deplatform, succeed, grow, water, imagine, enact, start, heal, bring justice, uplift, remember, protest, create

analog

analog

suggestive of a signal or a system of signals that varies in voltage in order to transmit information

— contributed by Trevor Tatham
45

Analog

Analog

I think of analog as something in the physical domain; something that’s not part of the digital sphere. A typical example is a clock face with “arms” that move to indicate the time (analog) as opposed to a clock where the numerals light up to represent the time (digital).

I also discovered while researching online, that mobile phones are both analog and digital. The communication signals going in and out are analog while the processing inside, specifically the speech and text functions are digital. In other words the analog part is a “continuous measurement or transmission of a signal” and the digital part uses a series of zeros and ones to process and store data. (https://techterms.com/definition/analog)

— contributed by Teresa Snider-Stein
46

Analog

Analog

One of my favourite pleasures of enjoying music through vinyl is the feeling of distortion and warping that comes from natural wear and degredation. This adds a layer of life to my music where the output is affected by the environment, (through temperature, improper storage, placement and use) and, ultimately, through my responsibility. Hissing, crackles, warbles, covers fading. Also, the physical exercise of moving, rotating, flipping the record adds intimacy with the music. A certain amount of care is required on all levels of interaction to maintain the experience as long as possible. But even with all of the care, the vinyl is subject to degrade. At some point, it will shift and become different from when I first acquired it. This is in complete contrast with the experience of listening to music digitally, especially in the streaming landscape, where files are flawless, perfect, ready on command. Aside from the choice paralysis that I often feel from the (seeming) infinity of digital music - digital music is binary. It's either working properly or corrupted.

I wish for a natural computer that is shaped and degraded by the environment, which adds a certain texture to my experience that is unique to me.

(adjective)

47
— contributed by Timur Fattahov

The not gate / diode is a literal gatekeeper of non-white components into white neighbourhoods

— contributed by Krystal Maughan

Anthropometry

Anthropometry

Simone Browne's discussion of anthropometry made me think of the many junk forensic "sciences" used in a mass incarceration schema. Pictured is bite mark evidence - a particularly egregious example of junk - that is rooted in the idea that the body holds truths that indicate criminality and, through measurement and statistics, we can eradicate evil from our midst.

— contributed by Sus Labowitz

Anthropometry

Anthropometry

A scientific ruling on the physical appearance of the body in measurements and proportions.
A scientific peeling of the very first physical layer of human: skin.

— contributed by Sara K.R.

Anti-Black Subframe

Anti-Black Subframe

an act of seeing within a normative white racial frame that positions black bodies as alien, primitive, corrupting, criminal, and unruly objects to fear in an attempt to naturalize subjectively-constructed social hierarchies that serve colonial expansion.

the anti-black subframe masks the violence of whiteness by displacing the homicidal proclivities of imperialism onto black bodies, re-defining black agential acts that challenge the white-supremacist imposition of a lived objecthood onto black bodies as violent.

— contributed by Lauren Monzon

Anti Black Subframe

Anti Black Subframe
56

Ruha Benjamin often discusses benches in her writing and how they can be weaponized in defensive architecture. Benches are a useful illustration of discriminatory design on the urban scale and she proposes using the same kind of noticing that feels displaced by an unwelcoming bench as a mechanism for better seeing the systems of oppression and power.

“Yet if we consider race as itself a technology, as a means to sort, organize, and design a social structure as well as to understand the durability of race, its consistency and adaptability, we can understand more clearly the architecture of power.” - p.91, Race After Technology

I saw this bench on my morning dog walk and was inspired by its quiet resistance.

— contributed by Sus Labowitz

Assembly Line Hysteria

Assembly Line Hysteria

A term coined by Signetics management in the late 1970’s to dismiss significant health concerns such as “dizziness, nausea, mental confusion and emotion problems” experienced by female assembly line workers. After men also complained, the company investigated and verified that the health issues were real and not a figment of the women’s imagination. Even though the women’s complaints were validated the three women who initially complained were fired. Further investigations revealed that Signetics had used high levels of toxic chemicals to produce semiconductor chips giving little regard to their workers health. We, as a society, should have learned from this; women are still not believed when they raise the alarm. Many are still shuffled aside, pushed into the dark, fired, removed from sight. Some advances have been made, but all women need to be made equal under the law. It’s time.

— contributed by Teresa Snider-Stein

Automatic Programing

Automatic Programing

Automatic Programing is when one writes code so that the computer itself can build on that code to write or run additional programs. The computer can take care of running these more basic and possibly repetitive programs while a human user can write code at a “higher abstraction level” focusing on specific and targeted programing activities. This differs from hiding data in response to privacy or security issues. Automatic programming allows the user to focus on the elevated coding and programing tasks while the computer itself runs the previously written programs in the background. This way the user does not need to heavily multi-task; they can just focus on their target coding activity.

— contributed by Teresa Snider-Stein
64

Automatic programming

Automatic programming

The paradigm following direct programming in which software is written at a higher abstraction and does not need operator input (input in this case being mechanical) to execute code and to switch between different programs. This replaces the programmer > operator > machine interface with a programmer > machine interface.

— contributed by Paras Sanghavi
65

Automatic Programming

Automatic Programming

Simply know as coding today it is the generation of programs by computer, usually based on specifications that are higher-level and easier for humans to specify than ordinary programming languages.

— contributed by Tristan Sauer

biometrics

biometrics

a way to measure and quantify that which is hardest to alter or obscure. for example, the human face can be modified in real time to be something else (i.e. plastic surgery). However, that type of operation would be a lot more complex and risky if it were to be applied to something like the iris - for an iris scan. In that way biometrics requires that we alter the most fundamental parts of ourselves for evasion. Raising the question of how much work are we willing to do to evade the machine eye.

https://www.sciencealert.com/images/articles/processed/eye-scanner_1024.jpg

— contributed by David Lisbon

Black Gooey Universe

Black Gooey Universe

If Connor, Lauren, Jessica, and Matt designed computer technology, it would:

  • No longer use optimization as a means of sidestepping or offloading accountability (https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/jul/02/facebook-mark-zuckerberg-platform-publisher-lawsuit)
  • Question the ideologies and values of what we consider to be a ‘functioning’ technology
  • Prioritize simplicity – avoid the “Swiss army knife” approach to technology design
  • Situate itself within a broader more holistic definition of technology.
  • Not co-opt the word “technology,” as exclusively digital (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quipu)
  • Be transparently accountable to the communities and lands impacted by their creation and use
  • Serve the needs of the communities itself by being built with rather than for communities
  • Be specific about who is included and also excluded from the design
  • Be homespun (

79

  • https://www.alliedmedia.org/)
  • Works on systems of trust (https://www.wired.com/story/we-need-to-build-up-digital-trust-in-tech/)
  • Develop at the speed of trust (https://www.akpress.org/emergentstrategy.html), rather than the speed of productivity (https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/former-boeing-manager-says-he-warned-company-problems-prior-737-n1098536)
  • Develop with communities defined by the size of trust
  • Be clear about the limitations of what it does and who it’s for
  • Understand that there is rarely a single ‘user’ and that to design only one user, rather than for communities of people(s) impacts the social bonds we feel responsible for and to
  • Stop imagining technology and engineer as ‘savior.’ Works outside of white ‘savior’ complex. (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Shing)
  • Ensure the human infrastructures responsible for new tech have the capacity to create systems that support distributed

80

  • knowledge and a multiplicity of imagined futures.
  • Acknowledge that no technology is for ‘everyone.’
  • Work within structural imaginaries that move away from binary/linear ways of knowing to cyclical, circular, elastic, and relational ways of knowing.
  • Make power structures visible.
  • Account for broader bodily / sensorial knowledge. (http://cc-catalogo.org/site/pdf/Pallasmaa_EyesoftheSkin.pdf)

Other references that surfaced during discussion. (https://www.are.na/connor-trotter/chat-6-9-20)

In collaboration with Connor Trotter, Lauren Monzon, Jessica Rajko, and Matthew Ross

— contributed by Jessica Rajko

85

Black Gooey Universe

Black Gooey Universe

it’s the day where the sun gets swept up by darkness. where black spills across the sky like jazz turned the world upside down. like trumpets shook rain from the ground and down came soil.

we ain’t on them old calendars no more - we move on ecological rhythms again. we been waitin for the eclipse to honor and remember that day we finally stole away into our own kind of refuge. when we lost the words for ######, and #####, and ######. when enough composted them into longing for a new language.

i light a candle in the morning and give thanks. each biological and chosen family across the town starts stompin and singin into the accordion-like floors of our homes - we are resourcing the town’s energy through our offering of grief and praise today. we shake and shake and call out to release the remnants of ancestral trauma

86

that still got a stronghold on us in our bones and in our blood.

these piezoelectric floors start harvestin our release and transmuting it into energy. someone able-bodied from each family gotta bring they conduit disc to the center today, charged by our prayer, as an offering. and we gotta come as stewards of our family’s dreams to the dreamkeeper so the prophecies can emerge to guide us until the next eclipse. it’s my turn to go.

i bring our conduit disc of obsidian, round and engraved with symbols that tell the story of our family, to the town’s hive. in my bag, i bring offerings for the spiders, for the bees, for the birds, for the stars, for the mountains, for the steel, for the glass, for the silica sand, for the iron ore, for the gold, for the bauxite, for the hafnium, for the tantalum, for the palladium, for the copper, for the boron, for

87

the cobalt, for the tungsten, for the aluminum, for the zinc, for the nickel. i practice recounting the dreams my family shared with me at the fire this morning till sunrise, chanting them to myself over again and again.

i get to the hive where the altar to the elements that make up our collective computer lie. folks weave in from across the town as representatives of their families and we each lay down our offerings and give reverence to the elements that allow us to communicate enmeshed with the other sites of refuge that emerged from the revolution. we each pour out water onto our offerings to account for our grief for the way these materials were mined in the past. we offer our thanks for their magic.

we each place our conduit discs into their respective places and turn them into the ground beneath us. if each family gave their

88

offering of grief and praise this morning then it will be enough to charge the computer. some people are more resourced than others and have brought more than one disc for folks who still have trouble dancing, singing and moving grief for their families. suddenly, as all of our discs wind into the ground, a bell-like vibration rings out and our bodies hum all over.

in a circle, we gravitate towards the hum and place our mouths against the sonoluminescent cone-like mics - we will whisper our family’s dreams from the night prior into the cones and the sounds will transfer into light before us; our dreams colliding and drawing into one another.

we grab hands and witness the dance of holographic light before us in awe. we thank the stars for their wisdom and wait for the patterns to be revealed and announced back to us. we wait.

89

90

At a neighbouring city, a similar moment is happening. The children are deepening their relationship with and respect for the technology. They perform.

We, tuned to the sound of the bell-like vibrations, the ringing of the city, and the energy boiling within, start to sing.

The discs start shifting, creating a certain rhythm and reacting to the results of the dreams and desires we offered; we all start dancing. As we stomp our feet, the thundering roars and the bright lights echo through the surrounding mountains. The stars are seen and reverberations can be heard from somewhere nearby, but ever so slightly.

The discs start opening up, revealing their vulnerable components. The children and their upbringing from the community are put to test.

91

The children who have been waiting to be initiated finally have their moment. They separate themselves from the group and perform to create enough energy and harmony, moving their bodies and following the maze of the discs. They must know and feel the inner workings of the machines, but more importantly, must all work together if they want to pass.

They understand the risks, the opportunities, the importance, the history, the ways of preservation, and receive the call to unite.

The community comes together again, each equipped with their own form to vote and decides whether the children have passed.

92

A small group climbs in the hills next to our city, running up smooth, grassy terrain. It is dark but their footing is steady, grooves in the rock faces worn with familiar prints. Up top, they lay down their belongings and bring out their own small discs, scattering them on the ground, hooked on low hanging branches, tucked into hollowed bark. They sit and look up at a clear sky, an obscured waning moon, a collective sigh.

After some time, some of the people begin to stir, a warmth in the air as the discs emit the faintest glow. The younger ones jump up and look toward home, light seeping out of its heart and spilling in all directions. They squint, hoping that in the shadows they’ll be able to see their friends dance. At once they laugh and spin, clapping each others’ hands, ruffling hair as they move. Their conduits sparkle in rhythm, illuminating all of their worn,

93

smiling faces. The conduits whir and blink like giant fireflies.

As blue and purple aura bursts from the city center, they look to the horizon and see dozens more beams of light miles away. The lights swirl in the air, colors mixing, a deep red grid to the west, a brilliant green diamond piercing through a cloud way north. The young ones have been accepted by all.

As the lights begin to fade, the remaining echos fall from the sky, small embers swept by the wind. One of them points to the coast and sees a soft flickering white, a city whose energy is weak. Another nods quietly, flashing their eyes towards the children, still dancing and unaware of the sight. Tomorrow they’ll report the sight to the community, form a group to venture over and help.
They grab the conduits and stack them together and prepare to rest. Their light will keep them warm

94

until dawn.

In collaboration with brontë velez, Timur Fattahov and Paras Sanghavi.

— contributed by Paras Sanghavi

Carte de Visite

Carte de Visite

During the Civil War era, in photography’s early days, people paid to have photos printed on small cards so they could share them with friends, family and business contacts either in person or via the US Postal Service. It was a way to keep in touch, share personal photos or promote a businesses or cause. One such carte de visite was made of the escaped, “freed” slave, Wilson Chinn, from Louisiana. The “instruments of torture used to punish slaves” are depicted on and next to Mr. Chinn and there is the brand on his face. This particular carte de visite, entered according to an Act of Congress in the US Southern District of New York in 1863, now serves as biometric evidence of the horrific, denigrating treatment of fellow humans held in bondage at this time in the USA. This technology could be used to inform and advocate for a change or is it taking advantage of the man in the photo. Where will the things we make with technology go? Who are they for? WIll they help or harm? What are the intended and unintended consequences?

Causal pleasure

Causal pleasure

The feeling that interactive software gives when it responds to a user action with a response that is exactly what the user expects. The pleasure comes from the instant feedback and the computer fulfilling its role as the executor of commands without much subjectivity or interpretation.

— contributed by Paras Sanghavi
126

Causal pleasure

Causal pleasure

A few of my friends have been really into Animal Crossing the past few weeks as it has skyrocketed in popularity. I’ve found the gameplay mechanics really interesting, as it seems to step away from many aspects of user amplification and instead require the player to manually do tons of small incremental tasks, tasks which in some ways are the immediate kinds of things that as a programmer I’d want to automate. For example, if I see an item on the ground but it is at a surface higher than my current one, I must walk up next to it, open a menu, take out my ladder, put it down, walk up the ladder, and then put the ladder away. Only then can I walk up to the item and pick it up. It’s made me really think about what I come to expect in software, which is that when something is clearly defined, the computer should handle the mundane aspects and instead leave me with

127

the parts that are exciting.

The problem with this is that I'm holding an implicit definition of mundane, which I can't actually articulate. If I want a higher level of amplification, then why stop at just the mechanics of a ladder? If the game sees an item within my eyesight and it is on a surface reachable by walking and ladder, should it just automatically take control and go through the motions of traversing and picking up the item, saving me the keypresses? Or moreso, should it just scan the island and do this for all items?

At this point, the game stops being fun, and reminds me how much better I am at identifying tasks to perform than the excitement that I desire.

— contributed by Paras Sanghavi

Cognitive Map

Cognitive Map

A concept put forth by Fredric Jameson, a Marxist political theorist, in his book Postmodernism, or, the Cultural Logic of Late Capitalism. It is a situational representation for the individual subject to make sense of the complex and underlying totality of society’s structures, often unseen to the individual. Cognitive maps are used to critique ideologies, which in turn, might be a form of ideology.

— contributed by Kevin He

Command-and-Control

Command-and-Control

My family lights candles some Friday nights over Zoom lately - my siblings, my parents, and my one remaining grandparent. In normal times, my grandmother, who is 95, is in relatively good health, but she is social and isolation hits her hard. We start these calls with a quarter hour devoted to trying to turn her camera and microphone on from afar (on just one device). She is frustrated by a sudden reliance on communicating in a way she loathes and feels inadequate at.

My grandmother graduated Phi Beta Kappa in math in the early 1940s - or, in her words, “I studied math because I never was any good at writing papers.” She worked as a statistician for the CDC after school to study flies for polio vaccine research. I don’t know if they used early computers for her project and I don’t want a tight little narrative where my grandmother pioneered computing and now struggles with her iPhone. And she does do well for the most part: she follows me on Instagram, reads the paper on her iPad, but she doesn’t relish in the joy of discovering a new technique. She sees what she’s forgotten, the ways my male cousins surpass her. This at least somewhat tracks with command-and-control: she is perfectly capable of operating her devices, but not of envisioning herself as mastering them.

150
— contributed by Sus Labowitz

conflict minerals

'Bias' is as malleable to define as is 'credible' so there's a handbook regularly updated for reporters/editors that explain things like 'appropriate sourcing' or examples of word choices that have implicit bias.

Dark Matter

Dark Matter

“The concept of dark matter might bring to mind opacity, the color black, limitlessness and the limitations imposed on blackness, the dark, anti-matter, that which is not optically available, black holes, the Big Bang theory, and other concerns of cosmology where dark matter is that nonluminous component of the universe that is said to exist but cannot be observed, cannot be re-created in laboratory conditions. Its distribution cannot be measured; its properties cannot be determined; and so it remains undetectable. The gravitational pull of this unseen matter is said to move galaxies. Invisible and unknowable, yet somehow still there, dark matter, in this planetary sense, is theoretical. If the term “dark matter” is a way to think about race, where race, as Howard Winant puts it, “remains the dark matter, the often invisible substance that in many ways structures the universe of modernity,” then one must ask here, invisible to whom? If it is often invisible, then how is it sensed, experienced, and lived? Is it really invisible, or is it rather unseen and unperceived by many? In her essay “Black (W)holes and the Geometry of Black Female Sexuality,” Evelyn Hammonds takes up the

190

astrophysics of black holes found in Michele Wallace’s discussion of the negation of black creative genius to say that if “we can detect the presence of a black hole by its effects on the region of space where it is located,” where, unseen, its energy distorts and disrupts that around it, from that understanding we can then use this theorizing as a way to “develop reading strategies that allow us to make visible the distorting and productive effects” of black female sexualities in particular, and blackness in general.”

Excerpt from Dark Matters: On the Surveillance of Blackness by Simone Browne

— contributed by American Artist

democratization

democratization

democratization (re: technology) isn't a word that makes any sense to me, i always get tripped up on what it should mean and doesn't. i like to think of democratization as being the act of making all things more democratic rather than making more things barely democratic. like what if democratization of technology meant we got to decide together how our work was used, what if our workplaces were democratic, our communities? what if technology actually gave us some kind of agency or enfranchisement? a say in whether our labour or data are used by cops or the military or financiers? a say in whether rare earth elements are worth the exploitation and suffering we enact to extract them? a seat on the council of maybe not burning coal just to mine a bunch of bitcoin with it? the worst part, for me, is the people who believe that technology literally produces democracy mean it in the most boring way possible. like thomas friedman saying that no two countries with a mcdonalds would ever bomb each

206

other (this did not turn out to be even remotely true) or that no two countries of the same global supply chain would declare war on each other (well they would but they'd think about it a little bit longer before they do). it is disappointing without end that anybody would think that jeff bezos running taylorist hellholes (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scientific_management) on 3/4s of the planet is democratic. my problem is that when the dominant voices say democratization they mean democracy of access, not democracy of enfranchisement, agency or autonomy

— contributed by angus fletcher

212

Determinism

Determinism

When Alexander Galloway & Louis Althusser talk about the determinism narrative of ideology – “in which ideology is understood as a system of total thought that may or may not determine things like human subjects[…] with the key issue being the industrialization of the body and mind into modes of efficiency and instrumentality”, I am reminded of a similar narrative embedded into the history of Software. Much like the industrialization of humans and labor, Software continually seeks to be further optimized, compartmentalized, functionally expanded, and abstracted into higher levels of structured programming. In short, Software—in both ideology and practice—is always developing itself to become more efficient and more “capable”.

Software wants to insert (or

213

implement) itself into all facets of life. This is evident in the way that start-ups, corporations, research institutions, hackathons, and academia have embraced and normalized techno-solutionism—the uncompromising belief that any and all problems can be solved through sufficient innovation and technology. Constant layering and growing, layering and growing, each time introducing new problems, and new solutions to those problems, and new problems from those solutions…

— contributed by Tyler Yin

218

Direct Programming

Direct Programming

A collaborative way of solving numerical problems between human and machine, requiring humans to give instruction, make connections, set switches, input values, and coordinate various physical settings of a computer.

This process of 'implementing mathematical routines' involved several time-intensive steps including breaking down a process into discrete instructions, planning wiring + wiring, assigning specific memory locations to all commands, managing input/output, subroutine libraries, sorting processes, etc.

Wendy Chun posits a historical connection between the overwhelming percentage of women who worked as direct programmers/operators and the emergence of digital computing, relative to “quintessentially feminine” inventions of weaving, sexual mimicry, and the power that something which cannot be seen can have.

— contributed by Lauren Monzon

Ecological Wealth

This refers to region-specific, non-man-made resources. When a specific environment has abundant natural resources to support the needs of its inhabitants and those inhabitants guard and maintain the balance of all living organisms and their physical surroundings, it is ecologically wealthy. Such an environment successfully maintains the life cycles of all its inhabitants replenishing itself. However, if the cycle's balance is severely disrupted this wealth can be depleted or lost completely leaving the ecosystem barren and lifeless.
While it’s not listed on the stock exchange, ecological wealth is a precious, unrecognized, undervalued commodity as witnessed by the numerous superfund sites in the San Jose and Santa Clara County as well as those around the world. (Side note: During the World Wars, the Anaconda Cable Company operations in the village where I live, Hastings on Hudson, led to the development of our own superfund site.)

— contributed by Teresa Snider-Stein

Epidermalization

At the pottery studio the other day with my hands in soft gray clays. Little pieces of earth. My mind is on Fanon and epidermalization ("the inscription of race on the skin"). Exploitation

False Consciousness

False Consciousness

The false consciousness that appears in the Matrix needs no explanation. Humanity is unknowingly trapped inside a simulated reality, or the Matrix. The term originally comes from Marxist Sociologist to describe " a way of thinking that prevents a person from perceiving the true nature of their social or economic situation." Perfectly defining the situation of humanity in the matrix who are less thinking in a way that prevents their perception and more simply unable to perceive. Neo (the one) is given the choice later in the film to break free of this illusion by being given a choice between a red and blue pill. Blue leaves him in the false consciousness and red breaks him free. Essentially, tracking back to the Marxist definition, the red pill allows him to perceive the true nature of his social and economic situation. The irony comes into place with the term red pill, which has been appropriated primarily by the right and more often the alt-right to describe their bigoted notion that "the truth is that women and liberal politics are oppressing men and white people." The history behind the matrix, it's influences and the term false consciousness all point to vastly different interpretations, that lean farther from the ideals of the right than anything they use the term to describe.

— contributed by Tristan Sauer

False Consciousness

False Consciousness

A belief that consciousness can be false.

I'm taken back to an interview between Bill T. Jones (choreographer) and Roger Berkowitz (political studies scholar). https://vimeo.com/17817161

They discuss the work of Hannah Arendt, and Bill says, "We never stop thinking [...] What happens when you brush your teeth. What happens when you wipe your butt after going to the bathroom. Do you just, disappear? I don't think so." If consciousness can be made false, who defines truth. What is good thinking? What is truthful embodiment?

Bill T. Jones dances "Floating the Tongue." It looks like this: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NOSsDHLooi0

The task of the dance goes something like this:
Phase one: Create a movement phrase. Keep it simple and don’t think too hard about it. Decide when the phrase has a logical conclusion. Rehearse this phrase so that it becomes habitual and you don’t have to think about its progression as you dance it. Dance it

258

repeatedly, until you can remember and understand its rhythm. It should be under 30 seconds to execute.

Phase two: Imagine you’re teaching a class. Dance the material and describe the movements simultaneously. Be as detailed as you can be. Describe each action, body part, direction, inflection, velocity as you do it.

Phase three: Do the material as purely as you can but allow yourself to access regions of your mind or psyche, unedited. Narrate the dance as you do it but allow these unedited thoughts to enter, try to keep your attention on the purity of the material, while being a present as possible with the thoughts that emerge in relation to it.

Phase four: What you are doing affects what you are saying and feeling. What you are saying and feeling is allowed to change the movement. Allow the movement to affect your internal landscape. Narrate this internal landscape and allow it to affect your movement. Return to the phrase as you continue, but allow this to happen organically.

Leah Cox (former company member) performs

259

the dance something like this: [starting around 5 min] https://vimeo.com/17814806

When I see both dance, I see how we try so hard to make tangible our inner urges while also refusing to make it something to hold. Sand through fingers.

— contributed by Jessica Rajko

Feminist history of the internet in NYC

Feminist history of the internet in NYC

In a Lower Manhattan walking tour led by Lydia Jessup, who is a creative and public interest technologist, Lydia shares stories of seven women pioneers who were instrumental in the development of computing and the internet in NYC. With her question of “what would a feminist internet look like?”, I speculate the connection between "Webgrrl" (a way for women to meet other women who were interested in and knowledgeable about the Internet) and the narrative of democratization of programming. The stories of feminist radical support networks, interdisciplinary collaborations, and maker communities seem to liberate and democratize the control system embedded in early computer programming. It offers the imagination to co-create caring, empathic, gender-neutral and more accessible cyberspaces and interactions.

262

Project reference: https://www.lydiajessup.me/walking-tour-feminist-history-of-the-internet/

— contributed by Miranda Shou

fetishism

fetishism

-An object, or something else “tangible”, having transformative power over the other bodies it interacts with.

-Chun uses the example of literal folders as icons on a computer desktop to mimic folders on an IRL desktop.

-Is there something about the structures of the interactions between software and hardware that's inherently fetish?

-The word itself originates from cross cultural interaction between Europeans and West Africans, beginning in the 16th century. Later popularized by Marx with "commodity fetishism" - the idea that an object exists as tangible good and as a good fundamental to social interaction.

Hardware

Hardware

Computer hardware refers to the physical parts of a computer, such as the central processing unit, computer data storage, graphics card, sound card, motherboard, etc. It is rendered visible to most as a visual identifier of a computer but rendered invisible by software, which has taken over in establishing a direct casual interface with the user.

— contributed by Kevin He
294

Hardware

Hardware

Hardware exists in the physical world. It’s a tangible thing you can touch, feel or see, but it’s beyond the decorative, it’s functional. It facilitates a process. As an everyday (non-tech world) example, let's consider door hardware; hinges, doorknobs and locks. The hinges securely hold the door in place but allow it to change position as needed by the human user. Doorknobs and locks provide security and access; they control the door’s movement. Those with the key, or even just the ability to turn the knob or latch may gain access to move in or out thru the door. The flow of people and objects thru the door is controlled by the door hardware.

Computer hardware, also in physical realm, is made up of tactile objects. The screen, case, keyboard and mouse are easily perceived. Additional internal physical components include the hard drive, the motherboard, random access memory, and various cards and chips. Buttons facilitate access. Various ports provide space for connections to a power supply, additional components, and access to flash or external hard drives. In a computer, the flow of information, people and things virtually

295

passing in and out requires hardware, objects in the physical world.

— contributed by Teresa Snider-Stein

Higher-level programming language

Higher-level programming language

A set of instructions used to coordinate/order another set of machine instructions. The development of higher-level programming languages marks the move from physical programming alongside a singular machine to abstracted programming software that is iterable across many machines.

A milestone in computing, higher-level programming languages facilitate users’ capacity to program their own problems without the physical need for operator expertise and cast out of focus the materiality of computing machines.

— contributed by Lauren Monzon
306

Higher-Level programming language

Semantically closer to natural language and more ‘readable’ by humans. More abstract than assembly and machinic languages. Iterable, allows for programs that are independent of a particular type of hardware and can run on any machine at least in theory.

Ideology

Ideology

"To characterize my ideology as hate whitey is accurate since the only whitey is system and ideology"
– Amiri Baraka

In the context of this week's readings, the quote above immediately brings to mind the foundations of the Software ideology in white, patriarchal violence. Baraka encourages us to see the construction of whiteness as an ideology in itself. A more concrete picture of weaponized technological critique arrives by way of Baraka as well as Gramsci, who noted in his prison notebooks that the term "ideology" was originally used to describe a "science of ideas," only later changing to mean a "system of ideas." In noting that ideology effectively becomes determined by historical-politcal rather than physiological factors, Gramsci introduces the notion of ideology as "terrain" akin to that of a battlefield.

Thinking of software and the narratives surrounding its history as a battlefield resonates deeply in my interest with taking direct action against digital surveillance practices and misinformation campaigns.

317

Ideology informs and is informed by tradition, which is in constant danger of "becoming a tool of the ruling classes" (Benjamin, Theses on the Philosophy of History). The same threat exists for software.

— contributed by connor trotter

Ideology (anecdote)

Ideology (anecdote)

One summer—I think I was 14 or so—when in Bombay with my family, I visited a bookshop with my mother. On the way there, maybe on the next block, we passed another bookshop I had never seen, which my mother described, sotto voce and hurrying me past, as “progressive.” It was a term that meant nothing to me; she explained that it was run by Marxists. I thought that sounded terribly exciting and bought a slim volume of the Communist Manifesto, which didn’t really cohere until rereading it a couple years later.

During the first Kochi Biennale, I lived in the vicinity for a couple of months. Its parent state Kerala swings between a mostly communist coalition and one anchored by Congress (centrists). There was a serious drought that year; I was told it only rains when the communists are in power.

Job Mortgage

Job Mortgage

In Jerry Kaplan’s book, “Humans Need Not Apply”, he suggests that one way to bridge the looming future unemployment gap, due to technological advances, is to use a financial instrument he describes as a “job mortgage”. It’s described as a way schools and industry can collaborate so that students can learn skills needed to fuel a particular industry. Financial incentives are offered on both sides to make this work. Students are not bound to accept a job offer and can change their minds, or course of study, but this would theoretically be a way for a student to master relevant skills leading to employment after graduation. I wonder if this could work? We clearly need to make major changes in our educational systems.

— contributed by Teresa Snider-Stein

People's Dictionary

People's Dictionary

An infinitely capacious, colorful lexicon of voices giving meaning to the breadth of our collective, lived experiences.

An assemblage of knowledge established within our mutual histories, liberated from predestined meaning, where there is no mandating of prescriptive language, nor any other tools of the elitist, and colonial literary industrial complex.

Toni Morrison reminds us that “oppressive language does more than represent violence; it is violence; [it] does more than represent the limits of knowledge; it limits knowledge.”

A People’s Dictionary is a subversive inquiry into the constraints of language and the other inherently oppressive structures which hinder our potential to imagine the Beyond. It asks questions like: “Which experiences inform theory? What is intellectual authority? Who gets to dictate what it means to be human?”

— contributed by z ai

416

Predictive Analytics

Predictive Analytics
417

Poetic Process, sus and Jessica

We took an iterative and cyclical approach to creating this poem moving in and out of formal structures and reflective conversations about how those structures work to expose systems of power, assumption, and whiteness--including our own. Listening to a talk by Wendy Chun later in the process helped us gain a sense of how the cyclical nature of our collaboration could be manifest in the final poem we created, which layers all the iterations on top of themselves generally resisting a linear structure.

Phase 1: Build a form.

In our first conversation we discussed the idea of using a “predictive analytics” structure to build material. The idea was to put ourselves through such a structure and see what it brought up for us. Sus folded in the COMPAS Risk Assessment form and created a Google Form based on some of the COMPAS questions.

In collaboration with Sus Labowitz and Jessica Rajko

— contributed by Sus Labowitz
418

Predictive Analytics

Predictive Analytics
419

Phase 2: Fill out form.

We both filled out the form for each other and reviewed the results. In a follow-up discussion, we reflected on how our responses reflect not only our biased interpretations of each other, but our own personal narratives. Since we don’t know each other well, we felt ourselves self-projecting onto the responses. We also discussed some of the conversations and poems that were shared in our class by other students. One major theme brought up was the notion of empathy. We talked about how our process of using a form to get at this notion of authentic response to the poem prompt surfaced our own Whiteness and reification of White structures to elicit an emotional and perhaps empathetic response that could be rendered into the poem.

Phase 3: Document our Whiteness.

This conversation about our own Whiteness led to the creation of this writing by Jessica to get at the White internal dialogue about rightness, authenticity, and how the fear of taking space ends up taking up space.

In collaboration with Sus Labowitz and Jessica Rajko

— contributed by Sus Labowitz
420

Predictive Analytics

Predictive Analytics
421

Phase 4: Make something.

At this point, we both felt stuck about how to wrap everything into a poem. Sus shared Wendy Chun’s talk (linked above), which led to an interesting back-and-forth on Slack. The following Slack conversation ultimately led to our final poem:

sus: thanks for this. not totally sure what a csv file is but this is a fun format! from our conversation, i returned to a Wendy Chun talk I like: Wendy Hui Kyong Chun: Habitual New Media and from it, the following thoughts:
is our whiteness inherent in the usage of the google forms feature? and the emulation of a carceral system? When we think about how to display our work, is it helpful to contrast it with the kind of risk assessment form we were playing with?
i think there's something to the notion of a friendship questionnaire as we consider a tech not rooted in white supremacy. Chun talks about the prerogative to "Build technologies that question the basic premise that memory should equal storage. That everything read in should be stored."
Chun also spends a lot of time on the linkages/leakages that allow social media platforms to exist. Our leakage (who we spend physical time with, who we communicate with, etc.) leads to the ability to have prediction in that space (friend suggestions, can you tag this person in a photo?, etc.). In the same way Wang's analysis includes a

422

multiscalar approach (prediction of crime vs election prediction), what place do Facebook predictive algorithms have in a prediction discussion?
Going off that, Chun quotes Eden Osucha: “Historically, white women’s claim to a protected interiority receives the widest cultural sanction insofar as white women are required to embody interiority for others.”
Chun also addresses this question of spatiality (and embodiment? not quite, but she hints at a critique of disembodiment): "In an era of networks, connections are habits. An edge, a connection is a spatial representation, a spatializing of a repeated or repeatable action. Behind every dead representation are vibrant acts of renewal. In an era of big data, in an era which correlation seems to trump causality, in which correlations are allegedly better predictors than causal relations. In an era of Hume, things remain if they do habitually."
A lot of thoughts and half thoughts! How to incorporate a meta poem hasn't revealed itself to me yet, but I'll keep tinkering. I also thought about physically suturing it all together. We'll see! See you later on ~~sus

Jessica: Hey sus - thanks for patiently waiting for my reply. There's a lot to chew on here. I'm hoping to listen to Wendy's talk soon, but I haven't yet. In this, I want to trust you with how best to contextualize your thoughts within what we create, as the deadline is Wednesday. Do you have any initial thoughts? Maybe we start with what we shouldn't write, rather than what we should. Do want to

423

chat about it? I'm free tonight.

424

Jessica: I also want to return to the prompt, which was to respond to a term in the list. https://www.are.na/block/7789035 The first term that comes to mind for me is "guilt," the second is "predictive analytics." I'm also listening to Wendy and thinking about her use of circular repetition in words. It gets me thinking about repetition and reframing. Saying the same thing over and over and over in slightly different variations to get at the way ideas/beliefs/identities/biases/habits get nestled into a web of repeated actions, behaviors, and internalized patterns of thoughts. I think (particularly bc we are working with a poem) thinking about our choice of structure will be as important as the content.
4:17
I am interested in her reordering of short phrases in a pattern some dancers call "retrograde" (reverse order) as a way to re-hear the context and content. Circling and adding. Like waves.
4:17
Just pulling out sensations and images.
4:20
Waves of short phrases that eventually emerge into longer phrases (like sentences) that leak information or context that leak some sort of new, perhaps more cutting and truthful information. 432

Programmer

Programmer

When I was in my late teens, I wanted to be a lighting designer for film and theatre. To this end, I sought out opportunities to work as a console programmer (also called a lighting board programmer) for live shows. I quickly noticed the inequity of these opportunities, as if you were allowed to gain access to a lighting board, it meant that you were a competitor and a threat and in competition with other “programmers”. There was also noticeable sexism, as I was once told by someone working for me (in the absence of my male supervisor) that they “would never take orders from a woman” and refused to do what I asked.
I began to notice that schools with more funding had access to better consoles, and therefore persons there had better opportunities to become professional “programmers”, and to make a living from it. This meant

433

philosophically that their ideas (motifs, the way they saw the world through that media) would be perpetuated, and those who lacked those opportunities would not. The process seemed on the surface to be democratic, but it weeded out those who had less access to consoles, prestigious mentors, or who could not work for certain initial wages for experience. This has always bothered me.

— contributed by Krystal Maughan

440

Quasheba

Quasheba

Pejorative stereotypical name for an enslaved woman of color in Jamaica circa mid-1700’s. The named woman was typically described as outspoken or strong willed. The term was used to mask the white male slaveowners colonial power trips and sexual assaults in order change the narrative and place the blame on the enslaved female’s supposedly “uncontrollable sexual drive”. This de-humanizing tactic was one way the white slave owner manifested and reinforced his power while shirking any responsibility or even admitting any awareness that his actions traumatized a human being.
A version of this tactic is still evident in American society today.

— contributed by Teresa Snider-Stein

Redaction

Redaction
456

Comic showing possible outcomes of redaction.

Throughout the illustration process, for me, redaction came to mean a power tool used by an authority to stitch and obscure transparent, common access to information.

In researching redaction, I was struck by how subjective the classification process is. It is common for government censors to redact entirely different parts of the same document at different times.

Historically, as with the Bible, redaction can be both additive and subtractive.

461

Reflection

Reflection

“Reflection is nearly axiomatic: the complete syntactic and semantic rules of a computer language must be defined and written into any environment designed to interpret, parse, or execute it. (As an aside: in the so-called natural languages the sis never the case, despite style guides and dictionaries, as unforeseen ‘inductive’ uses of language may be stumbled upon or invented without the blessing of provenance, whereas with software the unforeseen articulations of language are essentially dismissed out of hand as errors or ‘exceptions.’”

I wanted to challenge the slight negative connotation on computer languages as rigid reflection and the counterexample with natural languages Alexander Galloway offers in Software and Ideology. Though true, it is hard not to consider the sublimed cultural messages packed into the syntax and semantics of the so-called natural languages spoken by people. I’ve witnessed first hand how a misalignment in assumptions (arguably constructed by ideology) can lead to misinterpretation. I was born in the US, moved to China when I was 8, and returned to

462

the US for college. As a result, most of my mannerisms and views were heavily influenced by Chinese culture but I had retained my American first name and perfect American accent. During first encounters with people, those two semantic factors alone would lead people assuming I was simply another Asian American. However, when my mannerisms, shaped by the cultural norms in China, misalign with people’s assumptions, they tend to attribute those differences to personality and rather than cultural differences. On the other hand, an exotic name and accent would signal people to proceed with caution in communication and at least ask where they are from, establishing difference. The purpose of this anecdote isn’t to argue what’s right—both cases have pros and cons, but to simply point out a consequence of the complexities of language, which the author painted as a positive counterargument to the axiomatic nature of programming languages. This also leads to a broader discussion around communication and the establishment of expectations.

— contributed by Kevin He

skilled workers

skilled workers

A political phrase invented to justify underpaying and exploiting workers and not paying employees what they are worth. An admission by a business of not investing in their own employees but rather passing on those costs and responsibilities to the worker.
A term never quite used to describe the managerial elite within a company (who may not need to be skilled but rather can benefit from nepotism), but rather used as a smokescreen to encourage structured hierarchy (and for those at the top of the hierarchy, loyalty) among obedient worker bees.

— contributed by Krystal Maughan

software

software

some combination of:
- a mental model of how a computer is configured to accomplish some task (where do the patch cables on the eniac go? are any tubes burnt out? what am i being told to do? what am i trying to do?)
- the symbolic representation of that configuration (source code, patch diagrams, prose descriptions)
- the actual execution of that task on a computer (how we might observe the system state, the inputs, the outputs)

some arguments try to synthesize these understandings, some try to eliminate some of them (Kittler's There Is No Software suggests it's all just voltages in a machine, for example)

— contributed by angus fletcher

Software

Software

Digital fascial infrastructure - a connective tissue that both connects and separates different parts of our digital systems.

I have been fascinated with fascia lately - people with close ties to bodywork have started to focus in on our connective tissue as a means of healing and (re)balancing bodies. Unlike the more commonly studied muscles and organs, it has been largely overlooked until recently - partially because it's seen as a passive tissue. Fascia is incredibly visible, spreading across a body - but also invisible, connecting the parts of our bodies more synonymous with what people might consider the 'stuff of bodies.' It blurs the lines and distinctions between body parts and reminds us that our internal systems are literally interconnected and held together by something we've largely overlooked.

— contributed by Jessica Rajko

480

structured programming

structured programming

a way of programming that favours a hierarchical decomposition of a program. roughly:

  • think of your program as a broad series of steps
  • write down those steps
  • think about the steps in each of those steps
  • write down those steps
  • repeat until you have a program

if the only way you abstract steps is by subroutine or function calls (as opposed to using GOTOs or jumps), the resulting program is shaped like a tree, which is easier for other programmers to read and understand at multiple levels of detail. this choice to emphasize legibility implies a move towards programming as a collaborative or industrial process

— contributed by angus fletcher
481

Structured Programming

Structured Programming

Software engineering. The industrialization and standardization of higher-level programming languages, hegemonically requiring programmers to deal with abstractions over numerical processes. Structured programming means programmers create software using software, effectively eroding the distinction between programmer and user.

Importantly, structured programming emerges in an effort to control quality, costs, and programmers as well as their techniques, “protecting” programs from programmer alteration/imagination. Structured programming is generally considered successful when it hides—and therefore secures—the machine.

— contributed by Lauren Monzon
482

Structured Programming

Structured Programming

A secured computing system that is opaque in ubiquitous computing, while it lowers the barrier for programmers to code with the understanding of ones and zeroes (binary language). The system is an embodiment of distribution of power in the early field of computation. It later evolved into high-level programming languages.

— contributed by Miranda Shou

Suralimentation

Suralimentation
487

“In French, a suralimentation intensive, a revitalizing boost of energy. With this, the Caribbean is made an exotic, as well as an eroticized, source of power of the French colonial project.” (Dark Matters, Simone Browne)

When I searched for “suralimentation” in Google, I found that, along with the definition Simone Browne provides, the word describes an auto part in French that (I think) adds a surge of energy to an engine when installed. The image still is taken from a video on YouTube of a person discussing such a part in French. Thinking about suralimentation in this way, as a moment of a release of energy to supercharge an engine, made me think of Browne’s discussion of epidermal racial schema:

“I am taking epidermalization here as the moment of fracture of the body from its humanness, refracted into a new subject position (“Look, a Negro!” or “Look, an illegal alien!” or some other negatively racialized subject position.) In other words, it is the moment of contact with the white gaze - a moment where, as Fanon describes, “all this whiteness burns me to a cinder” - that produces these moments of fracture for the racialized Other, indeed making and marking one as racial Other, experiencing its “being for others.”” (Dark Matters, Browne)
